 Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Education Rehabilitation Project STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. ISSUES IN THIE EDUCATION SECTOR A. PUBLIC SECTOR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ISSUES 1.1 Overall educational effort. The share of the overall government budget devoted to education (14-15 percent) remains reasonable compared to other countries in the region and to OECD countries. However, education spending as a share of GDP hias fallen from nearly 8 percent in 1991 to below 6 percent in 1997; this has coincided with a period of sharp GDP decline. The result has been a sharp decline in both nominal and real budget allocations for education. Per student spending per annum at the primary level has declined steadily in real terms (constant 1992 prices) from just under $400 in 1991 to about $230 in 1997. The education sector has coped with this serious reduction in funding through a salary freeze at nominal 1994 levels and by reducing its budgets for everything but salaries (over 80 percent of budgeted funds) and utilities, such as rising heating and utility costs. To make matters worse, lower than expected revenues have caused actual expenditures to be 10- 15 percent less than what is budgeted. Because salaries are paid in full, capital investments, discretionary non-salary spending on educational inputs, and maintenance of facilities go largely unfunded. As would be expected in this situation, physical infrastructure -- old to begin with -- is deteriorating rapidly and the quality of education is at serious risk of decline. Given the importance of human resource development in stimulating a successful long term economic transition, the current share of GDP devoted to education should be protected, at a minimum, and should probably increase. Steps should also be, in conjunction with reducing staff numbers in the sector, to give non-salary educational expenditure priority when revenue shortfalls occur. 1.2 Needfor budget re-allocations. The formter Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's share of personnel expenditure in its public education budget (80 percent) is by far the highest in the region, and its budget allocation for capital expenditure (3 percent) is by far the lowest in the region, and only about half this amount is actually spent. Per student spending for capital renewal is below $6 per annum. Increasing spending for capital expenditure can best be accomplished through international aid, and is thus the major investment focus of this project. Increasing education spending on non-salary inputs within the current budgetary constraints can only be carried out through a combination of reducing teaching staff (see below) and shifting these resources to non-salary inputs such as teacher in-service training, educational materials and other expenditures which allow teaching and technical staff to do their jobs better. Given the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's economic status, spending on student welfare (about 7 percent of the budget) cannot be expected to decline significantly in the medium term; instead the focus should be put on better targeting these resources, particularly in higher education.
 -2 - 1.3 Controlling spending on personnel. In view of budget constraints, the Ministry of Education and Physical Culture (MOE) has no choice but to reduce the number of personnel working in the sector. The development of a plan to reduce teaching and non-teaching staff has been made a central focus of SSAC conditionality. This process is complicated by the well-justified constitutional obligation to provide education in multiple languages (Macedonian, Albanian, Serbian, Turkish, Romany and Vlachs), which necessarily results in inefficient student/teacher ratios given small groupings of various language groups. Pupil:teacher ratios are currently about 19:1 in primary and 16:1 in secondary, well below OECD averages. Due to political necessity, the MOE is expected to deal with the need for reducing teacher numbers through attrition followed by selective replacement. Thus, efforts to reduce the teaching force will likely not reflect a perfectly rational mix of needed teaching skills. Staff reductions for primary education are expected to be on the order of about 2 percent per year for at least the next three years. Reducing the numbers of highily specialized vocational teachers through means other than attrition -- mainly lay-offs and re-training -- may have to be addressed in the context of an overall restructuring of that sector. B. LEGAL AND INSTITUTIONAL ISSUES 1.4 Several key pieces of legislation -- including the laws on pre-school, social care of children, and higher education -- are not yet in place, leaving important issues unresolved. Among them are (a) the control of the pre-school budget, and the separation between social and educational services to pre- school children; and (b) the "degree" structure within secondary and higher education, which is still governed by the structure set out in a 1985 law of the former Yugoslavia. 1.5 Other issues, not currently under active legal consideration but of concern in educational circles, are the possible extension of compulsory education from 8 to 9 years, with the entrance age lowered from 7 to 6; the implementation of the Matura examination at the end of full secondary; the status of external qualifications, such as the International Baccalaureate (IB), in university admissions; and the implementation of a teacher appraisal system and its implications for the respective roles of inspectors and advisers. 1.6 Institutionally, the most pressing issues are: (a) the need for more effective communications between the MOE and its Pedagogical Institute (PIM), partly due to the geographical distance between the Ministry and the unsatisfactory housing for PIM which is located in temporary barracks far removed from the MOE; (b) the fact that the PIM Directorship has been vacant for two years; (c) the large and ever-increasing workload of the PIM due to recent changes in legislation that give it responsibility for curriculum development, textbook approval, in-service teacher training, inspections and evaluating student performance; (d) the internal structure of the PIM, which is organized by sector (pre-school and Grades 1-4, subject teaching Grades 5-8, secondary, vocational) rather than functions (curriculum, assessment, teacher training), leading to duplication of effort and inefficient use of expertise within the PIM; (e) the lack of a focus for the coherent implementation of education reforms, either in the MOE (there is, for example, no Planning Department in the MOE yet, although one is being proposed) or in the PIM (there is, for example, no cadre of testing/assessment specialists, and examinations are prepared by various people in each section). 1.7 With respect to quality assurance, the MOE-based Inspectorate mainly focuses on the organization and administration of schools, while the PIM concerns itself with matters of content and delivery. There is little contact between inspectors and advisers, and little mutual understanding and trust. For example, now that the law requires that all teachers must be appraised every two years, no
 - 3 - thought has yet been given as to how the two agencies might work together to design a quality monitoring system for schools with clearly specified, complementary roles for inspection and advice, and clearly specified ways in which a struggling or failing teacher might be helped rather than penalized. A second, but related, issue is that of adequate coverage for the country. With 30 Inspectors and approximately 150 PIM advisers the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia appears to be reasonably well provided for, but in practice school visits are irregular and follow-up is haphazard, partly because of the lack of communication between the Inspectorate and the PIM but also because of (a) inadequate travel funds; (b) lack of experienced advisers in some subjects or minority languages; and (c) lack of well-defined roles and co-ordinated plans. C. EQuITY AND ACCESS-RELATED ISSUES 1 .8 Traditionally, countries in the region have been able to reach near-universal access to basic education, with enrollment ratios in the upper 90s. However, the poorer countries now find it difficult to maintain access to basic education, with a marked decline in countries such as the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (93.2% in 1990 to 87.2% in 1994), Albania (100.6% in 1990 to 95.3% in 1994), Bulgaria (97.8% in 1990 to 91.9% in 1994), and Romania (98.3% in 1990 to 94.6% in 1994). At the same time, the more affluent countries in the region have been able to maintain their enrollment rates (the Czech Republic, Hungary). In secondary education, access is also deteriorating in the less affluent countries, with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's gross enrollment rates declining from 56.8% in 1990 to 52.3% in 1994. Access to higher education has traditionally been more restricted in the region, but is now rising rapidly in such countries as Hungary, Romania, Poland and Slovenia; in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, it has remained stable at about 12-14% of the age group since 1990.1 1.9 Provision. The Ministry and the PIM make strong, positive, and commendable efforts to ensure that all children in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, regardless of gender, color, national, ethnic or social origin, political or religious beliefs, property, and social status have equal access to, and opportunities in, education. Inevitably, however, there are differences of provision in rural and urban areas, and participation rates of some ethnic minorities (especially Roma) are less than those of others. There are certain inefficiencies in providing every curriculum, textbook, test, etc. in as many as four or even five languages, but in order to protect children's rights and to address minority inequities, these must be accommodated. 1.10 Sector inequities. Judging from the allocation of funds to the various levels within the system, there is some evidence that higher education and pre-school education are relatively over-funded compared to the compulsory (basic, 8-year) level. Pre-school in particular is heavily subsidized by the state. Since pre-school (and higher education) are non-compulsory and accessible almost exclusively to urban and more well-off families, there is a case to be made for re-allocating funding to the compulsory sector which is often the only schooling available to rural and poor children. 1.11 Gender. At the time of independence in 1993, there was a significant "urban drift" from rural areas into towns, often by families in search of work or better living conditions. During that period, the MOE closed a number of rural schools, especially those that were in poor condition or in areas where de-population was severe. Recently, families have begun to move back to the villages, putting pressure on the MOE to rehabilitate and re-open sclhools. Due to lack of resources and the almost complete absence of any capital investment budget for the MOE, about half of all rural schools are dilapidated, overcrowded and insufficiently furnished and heated. Such conditions are not conducive to improving equity between rural and urban communities, poor and more affluent children, and among nationalities. A further source of inequity is the lack, in some cases, of qualified teachers in some subjects or languages of instruction, but the MOE is making every effort to address this problem. 1.13 Family income. Several factors, especially the dramatic rise in unemployment (about 28% overall of the population between 18-57), lay-offs, arrears in payment of salaries, and a rise in living costs have increased the proportion of the population that lives at or below the poverty line. At the same time, the costs of schooling have gone up; parents pay for textbooks (at Grade 1, this can be as high as $50 per child; a set of Co-Ordinated Science textbooks for upper elementary (Oxford University Press, published in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia by Prosvetno Delo) costs about $17.50). Parents also pay for food (this can be as high as $30/per month) and for incidental expenses such as exercise books, supplementary readers, art materials etc. The average monthly wage in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is about US$ 175 equivalent. D. CURRICULUM-RELATED ISSUES 1.14. Current status. At independence in 1993, a "standing committee" was established to draft proposals for curriculum reform. Little real progress has been made until recently. "Concept" documents have now been prepared -- one for elementary education and one for secondary education --as well as a well-intentioned, but insufficient re-grouping of vocational subjects. All three of these documents were accepted by the Minister of Education in October 1996. Currently, however, 25 subject working groups have been set up under the PIM, each with a co-ordinator, to produce one new curricula. 1.15 Proposals have been made to reduce the prescribed, common core of the curriculum to 70%, with 30% available for schools and teachers to use more flexibly. Experience with this type of arrangement in other countries in the region, however, shows that teachers find it difficult to determine which "30% " of the curriculum is open to local variation; some interpret it to mean "30% of the timetable" while others try to introduce up to 30% "local content" into some, but not all, curricula. Through lack of training in local curriculum development, and lack of good supporting materials, most teachers simply continue to teach 100% of the prescribed curriculum. Effective use of curriculum flexibility will require training and resources. In addition, there is an obvious need to phase and co-ordinate the introduction of new curricula so that they will benefit the majority of pupils during their school careers, and to synchronize this with the introduction of new-style assessment types, teaching methods, and textbooks. 1.16 With regard to the elementary curriculum, the PIM staff state that they attempted, but did not succeed in including two innovations: (1) differentiation of the curriculum "by level of ability and
 -5 - interest"2, and (2) a change in elementary education from 8 to 9 years, with pupils starting at age 6 rather than age 7. Clearly, these issues have important pedagogical and financial implications and would need thorough debate before they are considered again. 1.17 At secondary level, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia shows the same -- although much more moderate -- shift of pupils away from vocational and into general education as other countries in the region (general education showed an increase from 22.9% in 1992 to 28.8% in 1995). This means that general secondary programs (gininazia) will increasingly need to cater to pupils of a wide range of academic ability. Curricula will need to be adapted accordingly. 1.18 Curriculum reform is particularly urgent iin secondary professional (vocational) education, which despite recent efforts is still far too specialized. The newly re-grouped system of 15 clusters and 111 separate "occupations" does not represent a significant reform of content or orientation and should be fundamentally reviewed on the basis of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's economic needs. In preparing the latest revision (October 1996), no research was done to determine whether these 111 occupations actually reflect what the labor market demands and can absorb; in any case, it appears unnecessary to have 4-year programs for the training of "pyrotecnists", or to make fine distinctions between "locksmith-welders", "mechanical locksmiths", and "metalsmiths" (each a 3-year course), or to offer a course for "green surfaces arrangers" (2 years, in the "forestry" cluster). A shift to broader, competency-based (rather than occupational) curricula is needed. 1.19 The development of an overall strategy to provide a better balance between general and vocational/technical education is of prime importance, especially since (a) the majority of secondary school pupils are still enrolled in vocational programs; (b) the majority of graduates become unemployed or fail to find employment in the occupation for which they were trained; and (c) highly specialized vocational secondary education is expensive, in terms of low student/teacher ratios and training equipment, as well as externally inefficient in tenns of the flexible skills demanded by the rapidly changing labor market. E. ASSESSMENT-RELATED ISSUES 1.20 Current status. There is at present no mechanism to permit the MOE to monitor standards in learner achievement across schools or over time, and no systematic data on the quality of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's education is collected or analyzed for feedback into MOE policy formulation. Assessment in schools is continuous and tests are teacher-made. Only the grading system is laid down by law (5-1 with 5=highest, and l=fail). Marks are aggregated by subject, and promotion to the next grade is determined by the number of passing grades at the end of the year. In general, repetition and drop-out rates are low in compulsory schools, and if they are high (as they were in upper secondary), measures are taken to help failing pupils and to ensure that they leave school with some qualification. There is no external test between (Grade 4 and Grade 5 (the transition from class-teaching to subject-teaching). Written tests at the end of Grade 8 are set by the PIM (Macedonian language and literature, and Mathematics). The 1995 Law on Secondary Education requires the introduction, by 2002, of an external secondary school-leaving examination ("Matura") in five subjects. With an annual education budget of $223 million, this reflects a worrying lack of commitment to quality assurance in the education system of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. In a diversifying system, where the emphasis should shift away from rigid control of inputs (curricula, textbooks, teaching methods), there will be an increasing need for monitoring the quality of "output": what learners actually learn and achieve as a result of their schooling. There is, however, no identifiable unit, or a cadre of trained experts, for assessment either in the MOE or in the PIM. No staff member has specialist training in educational measurement. * Assessment instruments are of low technical quality: they lack validity, reliability, and comparability in terms of difficulty levels and over time. Few resources or examples of good practice are available. * Teacher-made tests, test questions at the end of textbook sections, and PIM-set Grade-8 tests are heavily knowledge- and content-based, and ask for "factography" rather than application or higher- level skills such as problem solving or critical thinking. As long as the test requires the recall of facts, that is what teachers will continue to teach and pupils will continue to learn, regardless of any new curricula or teaching methods. Such tests have therefore a "negative backwash" effect on teaching and learning, and must be changed. * There is no attempt to equate the marks given by individual teachers: no guidance is given as to what level of performance a "5" or a "3" represents, and therefore the same level of achievement can receive quite different marks from different teachers, and different schools also apply different "standards" so that no conclusions about learner achievement can be drawn either across schools or over time. * There is an awareness both within the MOE and the PIM of the need to formulate "national standards", on the basis of which curricula and assessment instruments can be designed. However, there is no agreement as to what such "national standards" should look like, who should establish them, or how they could be made to link with European or international "standards". * The new legal requirement for the introduction of a "Matura" examination at the end of full (4-year) secondary education will be a useful focus for the development of such standards, and for the improvement of assessment-related expertise in the PIM and among teachers. * As competition for university places increases, there will be pressure on faculties to select students on more rigorous and "objective" criteria; thus the need for a more comprehensive and more professional system of assessment will grow. The PIM is well aware of this, and also acknowledges that there is a lack of expertise in modem assessment theory and practice; moreover, the PIM is aware that, ideally, the development of assessment objectives and models should be done in parallel with (and not after) the development of new curricula. F. TEXTBOOK-RELATED ISSUES 1.21 The main issues here are competition, fairness, quality, and price. There is wide support for liberalizing textbook provision in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and for ensuring that the new status of the state publisher, Prosvetno Delo, as a "social enterprise" is, in fact, no longer that of a state monopoly. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is fortunate in that (a) it already possesses a relatively flourishing private (general) publishing sector; (b) parents are becoming gradually used to
 -7 - paying for textbooks, and have shown themselves willing to buy high-quality supplementary materials if they are available at a reasonable price; and (c) some of the general book publishers have their own bookshops and marketing/distribution networks through which they could reach most schools in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The stage seems set for a fairly rapid and successful opening- up of the school textbook market. 1.22 At present, however, this market is not attractive to publishers, primarily because of the stringent legal requirements to produce textbooks not only in Macedonian but in all minority languages. While this is in itself commendable and clearly in accordance with the Constitution and the law, there is a danger that smaller, private publishers would not be interested in producing (or finanicially unable to produce) unprofitable small runs of textbooks - such as those in Turkish or Serbian - unless the MOE arranges subsidies for such books. The following further issues have been identified: * A major issue is Prosvetno Delo's present representation at various levels in the textbook approval procedure. If all textbook publishers in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are "equal", then they either should all be represented (e.g., through the Association of Publishers) or there should be no publisher representation on approval committees at all. * The transparency and fairness of the evaluation procedure should be investigated and improved. At present, the public perception is that the current procedure is far from being fair and open, with most important decisions made between the PIM (where many professionals are authors of textbooks) and Prosvetno Delo, which employs PIM members on its editorial boards. * As for content, Prosvetno Delo staff rightly point out that an overloaded curriculum leads to overloaded, fact-crammed books to ensure full coverage of the curriculum. Textbook reform must obviously go hand in hand with curriculum reform efforts, already underway. * The physical quality of the books will also need to be improved so that they last longer. Better- quality, sewn, hard-back textbooks are a better investment for families with more than one child, and indeed schools could attempt to formLalize the existing second- or third-hand market and/or adopt a rental scheme whereby books are recycled and made available to the next cohort at lower cost. G. TEACHER TRAINING-RELATED ISSUES 1.23 Pre-Service: Now that the new Education Laws of 1995 are in place, and curriculum revisions are underway, it is important that pedagogical faculties carefully review and revise their pre-service teacher training programs to reflect changes in pedagogy and teaching methods. For example, the introduction of an interactive learning approach in elementary schools will mean an entirely new role for teachers. Instead of being the source of all knowledge and instruction, they must become facilitators, helping children to be active in their own learning and allowing them to work in flexible groupings on varying tasks using a wide variety of books and rnaterials. In particular, pre-service teacher training should place far greater emphasis on the assessment of pupil leaming and progress, and less emphasis on teaching as if it were an end in itself. The following issues have been identified: * Institutions: There has been a clear breakdown in relations between teaching faculties and schools. There is a need to involve schools more fully in the development of training programs,
 -8- and to make sure that teacher trainees spend more time in schools doing student teaching before they are certified. * Content: There is a need to change the teacher training curriculum guidelines to give more focus to teaching methodologies and to practice teaching. Teacher trainees also need more exposure to new and innovative uses of learning aids. At the same time, a mechanism needs to be established to define and monitor standard competencies which students must achieve prior to certification. There is also a clear need to provide more opportunities for teacher training faculty staff to update their skills. 1.24 In-service: The introduction of educational reforms always relies heavily on in-service teacher training, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's reforms will require innovations in this field given the lack of resources to undertake traditional in-service training workshops for all teachers in the medium term. At present, however, the PIM is severely over-stretched and will not be able to deliver such a campaign without developing new strategies for providing this training. Outside support will be essential, particularly in areas where the PIM's own expertise is lacking. The following issues have been identified: * Budget: Funding for in-service teacher training in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is woefully inadequate by any measure. Of the $60,000 equivalent budgeted for in-service training in 1995-96 (out of the $223 million public budget for education), only 25 percent was actually executed. Financing for this essential educational input needs to be increased and executed. * Strategy and Planning: A new strategy for carrying out in-service teacher training needs to be developed which focuses on a "cascade approach" in which "mentor teachers" or "mentor schools" are used to deliver training at the school level. Once a new strategy has been identified, mechanisms will need to be developed for planning and prioritizing training needs. In addition, a mechanism should be found for providing schools with up-to-date information about new developments in education. The eventual goal should be to expand the range of training providers, as it is unlikely that the PIM will ever have adequate capacity to provide all required in-service training. * Content: Recent in-service training initiatives have been overly short and superficial -- partly due to the severely limited funding for these activities. Focus needs to be given to increasing and monitoring the quality of training that is delivered and to making sure that training addresses teaching methods as much, if not more than, subject content.

THE RECOVERY OBJECTIVES FOR EDUCATION AND THE BANK'S RESPONSE 2.1 Given the institutional weakness of the MOE, it will not be possible to address the broad range of issues identified above all at once and in a well-coordinated and effective manner. Nor is it possible at the present time for the MOE to develop a detailed, coherent and realistic strategy for addressing these issues in the medium term. In fact, the development of such a strategy -- best carried out by the people of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia themselves as opposed to relying on drafting by external consultants -- will entail a participatory process that will require several years and significant external support. In the mean time, there are a number of initiatives that can be undertaken in the near term (a) to help the MOE prepare its education strategy and related policy reforms, (b) to help the MOE improve its capacity to manage public resources more efficienitly, and (c) to have an immediate impact on improving the quality of education delivered in the system. 2.2 Development of a medium term strategy: The MOE is currently negotiating with UNESCO/UNDP to fund a participatory process aimed at defining long range education goals and a medium term strategy for achieving these goals. UNESCO staff have drafted an agenda and terms of reference, aimed at dissemination of information and consensus building, and UNDP funding is currently being considered for the undertaking. If this fundling does not materialize, alternative sources of finance for this initiative will become a priority for the MOE and other interested donors.3 In addition to this initiative, Japanese Trust Fund resources have been used by the Bank to finance background papers and recommendations, as well as project proposals, in the areas of education finance, assessments and curriculum, teacher training, textbooks and school mapping. These documents, which are currently available, will provide a foundation for policy discussions and help expedite the development of detailed sub-sector goals and strategies. The development of a long term strategy for education by December 1998 may be a formal conditionality under the Social Sectors Adjustment Credit (SSAC). 2.3 Improving management capacity and reforming institutions: Like development of a medium term strategy for education, improving management capacity and reforming institutions in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's education sector is a medium to long term undertaking. But, a good start can be made to achieving these goals over thie next two years. The initiative aimed at developing a medium term strategy is itself a tool for improving planning, analysis and management skills within the MOE. The initiative calls for creation of an Education Planning office in the MOE which will serve as the institutional focal point for ensuring a more rigorous approach to public resource management. The development of a school mapping data base and aL three year school rehabilitation program as preparation for this project is an important indicator of the MOE's commitment to improving its management capacity. In addition, donor investment activities in the field of curriculum development and teaching methodology, reform of secondary technical and vocational education, student assessment, teacher IDA financing for this initiative was rejected by the MOE based on UNDP/UNESCO's expressed intention to provide financing and the Government's general desire to reduce to an absolute minimum the borrowing of IDA funds to finance technical assistance.

The first priority in terms of having an immediate impact in the classroom in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is to mobilize investment resources to improve the learning environment in schools of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, particularly in high poverty areas where schools tend to be in the worst physical condition. Improving the learning environment in schools of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is the main short term goal of this project. A second immediate priority is to continue and even accelerate the process of improving the quality of educational inputs. The Pedagogical Institute of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, working closely with UNICEF, has already made significant progress in updating primary school curricula grades 1-4 and introducing an interactive teaching methodology in pilot primary schools. This success will need to be expanded, both in terms of reaching other grade levels and in terms of making sure that other educational inputs such as teacher training, textbooks and materials are updated to respond to the curricular and methodological reforms. Each of the capacity building activities included in this project is also aimed at having a direct short term impact on improving educational inputs in the schools. 2.5 The Bank's response to the above objectives is to respond quickly by devoting the largest portion of its available investment resources to primary school rehabilitation, which is the MOE's highest investment priority, and to devote a smaller share of resources to leveraging the support of other donors aimed at capacity building, institutional development and improving the quality of educational inputs. At the same time, through preparation and eventual supervision of the SSAC, the Bank will have a major input into the development of the MOE's long term strategy. There is consensus in economic literature, generally accepted in the Bank, that investment in humaLn capital generates a positive economic return to both an individual and to the society at large. A variety of research has shown what is intuitively evident: in a country at the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's stage of development and transition, investnent in improving the quality of learning inputs such as curriculum, textbooks and teachers has a powerful impact on improving student achievement and earning potential. A growing number of studies suggest that investment in school infrastructure also has a significant impact on student learning, particularly if it is done in conjunction with qualitative improvements in other inputs to the education system. Investment in severely damaged and unsafe schools, such as those found in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, has additional benefits in terms of targeting public resources on the poor and averting a potential loss of life (the formerYugoslav Republic of Macedonia is located in an earthquake zone). 4.3 The calculation of social and individual rates of return to education for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has not been deemed necessary for justification of this project for several reasons: (a) comparable rate of return analysis exists for other countries at the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's stage of development and transition; (b) such an analysis in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, at this time, would likely be highly unreliable given data constraints and distorted incentives due to labor market distortions, the current quality problems in education and high unemployment; and (c) the project is small, simple and, because it is focused on targeting high poverty areas, well-justified on equity grounds. The social rate of return to education in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia -- particularly for primary and secondary education -- is likely to be significant given its focus on broad societal values and other externalities, as well as labor productivity/income. It is likely that a proper calculation of the individual returns to investing in primary and secondary education is somewhat low due to the limited dispersion of wages in the country and high unemployment. The limited wage dispersion can be attributed in large part to the public sector dominated labor market that does not accord a significant wage premium to more skilled workers. Improvements to the quality and relevance of education -- which are the objectives of this project -- and the private sector led economic growth which is occurring, should jointly create an environment that will increase the individual rates of return to education in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, as well as the social and economic benefit to society at large. 4.4 Linkage to CAS. The Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy, (Report No. 14739-MK, dated April 19, 1995), which was presented to the Board on May 16, 1995, includes the following strategies for investment lending: (i) assuring adequate infrastructure for economic growth; (ii) supporting critical adjustment and development efforts; and (iii) helping to mobilize resources from both official and private sources. The Education Rehabilitation Project responds directly to these strategies. Adequate primary schools -- particularly in high poverty areas -- are essential infrastructure for long term economic growth and transition. Through a focus on educational quality, the project is also aimed at
 - 18- making the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's education system more responsive to the needs of an emerging market economy. Finally, a high priority has been given in this project to mobilizing other resources for education development and to aid coordination in general. The next CAS is likely to give particular priority to the need for investing in human resource development in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. 4.5 Public/Private Justification. In the future, as with most developed market economies, education in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is likely to be financed and provided by a mix of public and private institutions. Private schooling will eventually be needed to serve the diverse educational needs of the population (particularly in secondary and higher education), to reduce public spending on higher income students most likely to opt for private schools, and, potentially, for providing competition for the services of the public school system. But, as in most developed market economies, a modern public education system is likely to remain the main provider and financier of education in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. An efficient and responsive public education system in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia will continue to be necessary in the long term given the negative impact that a fully private education system would entail because of: (a) financial market imperfections (inability of individuals to borrow against human capital); and (b) the inability of private providers to capture the externalities (more civil society, greater social responsibility, and a more uniform and highly educated population, higher labor productivity) generated by an educated work force for the country as a whole. The private contribution to public education in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is steadily increasing at pre-university levels, where parents pay for books and educational materials and contribute to school maintenance and operations, and at higher education, where significant fees have recently been established and where student contributions to boarding and educational inputs are increasing. 4.6 Policy Environment. A description of the Government's policy reform efforts and the Bank's strategy for supporting those efforts -- mainly through the SSAC -- were included in Section B. It should be re-iterated that the Government is committed to the following medium term policy goals: (a) to manage public resources for education more efficiently; (b) to improve the quality of education inputs, including teachers; (c) to reform the overly specialized secondary education system and make it more responsive to the emerging market economy; and (d) to involve private sector publishers in textbook production. 4.7 Analysis of Alternatives. Several alternative project designs were considered: the first alternative was no Bank support at all; Alternative 2 was to focus IDA funding for the project more heavily on capacity building objectives; Alternative 3 was to increase the amount of Bank funding for the project; Alternative 4 was to provide financing in support of secondary or higher education rehabilitation and reform; and Alternative 5 was to focus IDA funding on capital investment and work closely with other donors to build capacity in the sector: Project Not Financed. Without the project, conditions in schools of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia would continue to deteriorate at an accelerated pace and cohorts of students -- particularly those in rural and high poverty areas -- would continue their education in pedagogically inappropriate and unsafe physical environments. It is unlikely that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's serious problem of a depleting capital stock would be addressed appropriately in the medium term. On the fiscal side, without the project, the Government or beneficiaries would be expected to incur higher recurrent costs over the continued life of the school and a higher capital cost of rehabilitating an even more damaged school building in the future.

 - 27 - 6. BENEFITS AND RISKS 6.1 Benefits. Through improving the environment for leanling, the proposed project will have a direct positive impact on the quality of education for about 15,000 children (about 6 percent of primary enrollment) in high poverty areas of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. In addition, enrollment ratios for primary education are expected to increase in high poverty areas as school facilities are improved. The project will also have a positive medium term impact on learning for all primary age children in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia through improving teaching skills and teaching methodology, improving the quality of textbooks and improving the quality of examinations, which provide a standard toward which children and teachers work. In addition to the project's direct impact on the quality of education delivered in the classroom, the project will help improve the capacity of the MOE to improve the quality of education inputs, to develop and implement programs and to manage public resources more efficiently. This latter benefit has already been partially achieved during project preparation through development of a school mapping data base, In the long term, improving the quality of education will stimulate economic growth through increasing the productivity and flexibility of the work force. Lastly, the project will help the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia leverage additional grant funding for education, and permit Worldc Bank staff to provide technical advice to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia during supervision. 6.2 Risks. The risks attached to this investment are low. Dilapidated primary schools will be rehabilitated in high poverty areas. The risk that these schools might not be adequately maintained will be addressed by requiring that a contract is signed between the community and the central ministry in which the community undertakes maintenance responsibility. There is a risk that the textbook pilot financed by the project will fail to prove sustainable. However, if it does fail, a number of books will have been delivered into the hands of students, and the MOE will have attained valuable information -- for a small price -- on how they wish to structure their textbook sector. Finally, there is a risk that institutional changes and capacity development in the fields of teacher training, curriculum development and students assessments will be slow in forthcoming. This risk has been partially addressed by requiring a commitment, in terms of recurrent expenditure, to these activities under the SSAC, and by making certain institutional changes conditions of effectiveness and/or disbursement under the Credit. The focus on tight aid-coordination under the project also serves to reduce risk in terms of the consistency of approach among the donor community. If progress is slow, the donor community will have no alternative but to re-evaluate its approach and continue providing technical assistance and training at the working level in the medium term.

 - 37 - APPENDIX 3 Page 1 of 4 FORMER YUGOSLAV ]REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA EDUCATION REHABILITATION PROJECT School Rehabilitation Overview Introduction I. During the 1996-97 school year, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia supported 1,046 public primary school facilities for its approximately 260,000 primary pupils. About 640 of these facilities are comprehensive schools, meaning they cover grades 1-8, as well as increasingly, in urban areas, kindergarten. Slightly less than half of these comprehensive schools are considered to be located, by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia population density standards, in rural areas. The remaining schools cover grades 1-4, and are predominantly located in rural areas. Nearly all rural areas in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are considered high poverty areas for the purposes of this project. Pupils are organized into 10,220 classes ('grades 1-4 are teacher specific and grades 5-8 are subject specific). Nearly all schools in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are double shifted, and some triple shifting exists both in rural and urban areas. 2. Current Ministry of Education and Physical Culture (MOE) estimates are that approximately 250 primary school facilities, of wlhich about 200 are in rural areas, currently suffer from serious physical problems and/or structural faults which render them unsafe (the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is in an earthquake zone) and serve to distract and demotivate students and teachers. More than half of primary school facilities in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia were built before 1960, and nearly all of the 250 schools identified as having serious physical problems fall in that category. In addition to structural faults which could cause schools to collapse in an earthquake, most of these schools suffer from a range of physical problems including: inadequate roofing, progressive foundation erosion, non-functioning sanitary facilities, lack of water and sanitary facilities, inefficient and/or inadequate heating, inadequate lighting, and lack of adequate classroom space. Investment Program Ranking 3. In order to begin to manage public school facilities more efficiently, a working group of engineers in the MOE began preparation of a school mapping data base in early 1997 with support from the SSAC Japan Grant. This data base is the first step in the MOE's efforts to develop a comprehensive management information system. The short term objective of this project is, however, two fold: (a) to prepare a three-year school rehabilitation investment program; and (b) to begin the process of rationalizing school facilities in terms of the potential for consolidation. 4. Significant progress was made during the first half of 1997 in terms of collecting information on the physical status of schools, as well as on basic educational and demographic information. This information has allowed the MOE to begin the process of ranking schools by a five step level of priority for rehabilitation. The MOE's first level priority is given to schools with serious structural faults which pose a threat to the safety of children. Within this category, enrollment numbers and the degree of overcrowding is used to give further priority to schools. All schools to be financed
 -38 - APPENDIX 3 Page 2 of 4 under the proposed project fall into this first priority category. A second level of priority is given to those schools which suffer from serious physical, but non-structural problems which hinder the learning environment (see examples above). Schools in this category are also further prioritized by enrollment numbers and the degree of overcrowding. A third level of priority has been given to schools with physical problems which are not currently urgent but where these is a risk that physical quality could begin to deteriorate. Levels four and five are allocated, respectively, to older schools (more than 20 years) which are relatively well-maintained and to schools that will not need significant investment for at least ten years. A similar exercise has been carried out for schools at the secondary and pre-school levels. 5. As mentioned above, approximately 250 primary schools, or one quarter of primary school facilities, currently fall into priority levels one and two in the MOE's ranking system. Although the information is or will soon be available in the data base, the MOE does not currently use rural-urban or poverty indicators as criteria for prioritizing schools for rehabilitation for its own purposes. However, the data base does make two further important distinctions that have an impact on school ranking. One is the case of low-capacity utilization, and the other is the case of schools located witlhin four kilometers of another school (numbers for both these categories will be provided by negotiations). Schools which fall into this category are being earmarked, and the MOE is committed to undertaking a serious analysis, as part of the overall school mapping exercise, to consider the potential for consolidation and/or adoption of multi-grade teaching techniques (which are already used in many rural schools). Because there are more than enough level one and two schools, which do not fall into these low utilization and proximity categories, to construct a realistic three-year primary school investment program, the rationalization of the primary school network on these grounds is not an urgent issue, at this time, for defining investment priorities. However, the MOE is aware that such efficiency issues are a high priority for the Government, and will need to be addressed in order to justify both external and Government resources for capital investments for education in the future. It should also be noted that the need to deliver primary education in multiple languages and ethnic sensibilities in terms of community school facilities are legitimate constraints to be addressed in the process of rationalizing Macedonia's school infrastructure. World Bank Selection Criteria 6. Schools to be financed under the Education Rehabilitation Project will be selected from the MOE's priority investment program using the MOE's internal ranking system to establish priority. In addition, the Bank has requested that the following general criteria be applied: (a) selection should be limited to primary schools in keeping with the overall project rationale; (b) the schools must be in a state of serious physical deterioration which poses a threat to effective learning as well as to the safety of children (levels I and 2 of the MOE ranking exercise); (c) the schools must be in high poverty areas and preferably in rural areas; (d) the schools must not have declining enrollment over the past five years, and must be used at full capacity or be overcrowded; and (e) no school should be located closer than four kilometers to another primary school unless the potential for consolidation has been explicitly explored and communicated to the Bank. The following points provide more detail on specific criteria:
 - 39 - APPENDIX 3 Page 3 of 4 * With regard to (c) above, the Bank has worked withi the MOE and the Statistical Office of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which has recently participated in a World Bank-financed Poverty Assessment, to define high poverty areas in the context of education. For purposes of this project, high poverty areas are defined as all rural communities with populations of less than 10,000, and those suburban or semi-urban communities in which more than 30 percent of adult residents are receiving some form of social assistance payments. * With regard to (d) above, high priority has been given to addressing overcrowding problems -- including triple shifting -- which serve to reduce learning time and distract teachers and pupils from learning. The need for double shifting in most schools and the MOE's standard for maximum class size -- 30-35 students per class -- will be used as standards for rehabilitation designs. In the case of severe and consistent overcrowding, limited extensions of classroom facilities will be accepted. * With regard to (e) above, the Bank will only finance schools which are located within four kilometers from another primary schools on the basis of written justification which demonstrates the lack of potential for consolidation. 7. Applying the above criteria to its own ranking system, the MOE will identify 50-56 priority schools to benefit from financing under the project. The Bank will verify the selection process and visit schools on a sampling basis prior to final approval for financing. Construction Standards 8. Many older schools in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia do not comply with Government building regulations concerning structural safety (particularly seismic protection). Most of these schools also do not provide the appropriate physical environment for learning that are prescribed in the current MOE standards for pre-university building facilities. The design and scope of rehabilitation interventions in schools to be financed under the project would, therefore, incorporate the minimum standards summarized below. * Structural Safety: All buildings to be rehabilitated will be structurally reinforced in order to comply strictly with the latest provisions of the National Building Code, in particular, those that pertain to the seismic resistance of the building structures. * Materials and Construction Methods: No asbestos materials will be used in the construction or rehabilitation of the schools. In the process of rehabilitation, appropriate measures will be introduced in the construction contracts concerning the safe removal and disposal, by the works contractors, of any asbestos materials found in the buildings to be rehabilitated. * Student Capacity: School facilities will be rehabilitated or, in limited cases, extended in such a manner that the total school enrollment can be accommodated into two shifts. As a rule, classrooms will be designed to seat 30-35 students. Kinclergarten classrooms should normally accommodate 20- 25 students. The average dimensions of these classrooms (i.e. square meters of floor area per student) will be in accordance with the MOE's established norms of at least one and a half square meters of space per child. A limited number of schools located in isolated/remote rural areas, where
 - 40 - APPENDIX 3 Page 4 of 4 students have to commute long distances in order to attend classes, may be rehabilitated to accommodate only one shift. It is unlikely that small schools where multi-grade teaching is required, will be justified under the program due to the Government's desire to reach the maximum number of pupils with scarce investment resources. However, in such instances, rehabilitation designs would take into account the size and number of classrooms needed for multi-grade teaching to occur. Amenities: The amenities to be provided (if not available) and upgraded in the affected schools are the following: (i) Academic facilities: - appropriate number of classrooms and general purpose common rooms - faculty room and administrative space - library with a small reading area - some limited school furniture (ii) Utilities/Other Features: - sanitary facilities for students and teachers - appropriate waste/sewage disposal - drinking water - heating: central heating units for larger schools; room/space heating units for smaller facilities - electricity (also in remote rural areas if available) - fire protection and emergency escapes - access facilitated for disabled students - security measures (as appropriate to protect loss of property) Exclusions from Project Financing: 9. The following types of interventions will not be included for financing under the project: - rehabilitation of student boarding areas - rehabilitation of school auditoriums for large congregations/cultural activities - rehabilitation of vocational/industrial workshops - provision of pedagogical equipment (e.g. laboratory/office equipment) - installation/rehabilitation of air-conditioning systems - installation of telephone/telecommunication systems Rehabilitation Costs: 10. Rehabilitation costs were based on a unit cost of US$200 per square meter of building area to be repaired. Thus the total rehabilitation cost of a damaged school is equal to the gross existing floor area of the school (aggregate areas of all floor levels), multiplied by the unit rehabilitation cost. Extensions of facilities were based on a unit construction cost of about $350 per square meter. No new construction will be financed under the project.

doc.abstracts: The Education Rehabilitation Project for Macedonia has three objectives: 1) to improve the learning environment in high poverty and predominantly rural areas; 2) to improve the quality of educational inputs; and 3) to strengthen the Education and Physical Culture Ministry's capacity to carry out teacher training, student assessment and curriculum development. The components to achieve these aims include: 1) rehabilitating and furnishing 50-56 dilapidated and dangerous primary schools in poverty areas; 2) facilitating teacher training reform and developing a new system for producing and financing piloted textbooks; 3) piloting a new teacher-in-service training strategy, developing capacity for student assessment covering core primary subjects, and establishing a school mapping database.
